item.title: Figured it out :)
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:9, topic:526458”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=645203.msg4340726#msg4340726 date=1375133552]
+1 for Django. Always loved the language, but I’ve never seen Flask. Thanks, I’ll take a look at it.
[/quote]
Flask is very, very flexible whereas Django isn’t as much. I mean, Django is good for fast development but if you have enough time you should definitely use Flask. You should also take a look at pyramid, another good python framework.[/quote]Alright, thanks! I’ll be sure to check them out. This could be some fun, other then the fact I’ll be ripping my hair out at times, yeah.

Read full topic

item.title: Figured it out :)
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

Uncalled:

+1 for Django. Always loved the language, but I’ve never seen Flask. Thanks, I’ll take a look at it.

Flask is very, very flexible whereas Django isn’t as much. I mean, Django is good for fast development but if you have enough time you should definitely use Flask. You should also take a look at pyramid, another good python framework.

item.title: Figured it out :)
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:6, topic:526458”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=645203.msg4340425#msg4340425 date=1375109377]

Don’t know of any specific tutorials, but here’s what you need to do… (will be tutorials/example of each on the internet somewhere)

  • Create a mysql database, with a single table that has one field - ip_address.
  • Get the IP address of the user
  • Run a SELECT query on the table to see if the IP address is already there. If it is, don’t show the quiz etc.
  • If it’s not, show the quiz
  • When the quiz is completed run an INSERT query on the table to add the IP address

You could just write the addresses to a file if you wanted to avoid creating a database, but that makes things harder in the long run and its a bit of a shitty way of doing it.

Writing them flat file is an incredibly slow and painful way of doing it, databases are much cleaner and more effective in this example. Be sure to use either mysqli or PDO since they support prepared statements and ultimately minimize exploits that can be made. PDO also completely excludes SQL injection as a form of hacking so you’re much better using that. If you need some examples, let me know and I’ll whip some up.
[/quote]
+1, PDO is awesome. Never see anyone using it here :([/quote]
Most people who bother to do website development here either use it or use a better language than php. Theres still a few stragglers using mysql_ functions but that’s soon beaten out of them with a shitty stick. The only reason I still use php is because I have done for the past 4/5 years and its just a habit to use it now. I highly recommend anyone who’s just getting into website development to use Sinatra, Express or something python based like Flask or Django.

Read full topic

Be sure to use either mysqli or PDO since they support prepared statements and ultimately minimize exploits that can be made. item.title: Figured it out :)
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

How secure do you want this to be? You can do it with either JS or PHP using cookies. But if you don’t want people just deleting the cookie you’ll have to use PHP and log IP addresses.

Read full topic
